title: As a 13 year old, should I continue learning programming? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is no purpose in asking this question unless programming is causing some strain on some other aspect of your life. If it is, neither myself nor anyone not close to you could provide a fair answer. So weigh the difficulties and decide for yourself what you wish to do. Whether the problem is feeling that you are becoming too distant from your family, that its standing between you and getting homework done, or some other such situation, I cannot aid you more than I already have. If you are not experiencing any form of strain other than the typical difficulty of solving problems and everything you’ve said is true, but you still felt the need to ask this question, determine why you are uncertain about continuing. If it is for any of the following reasons, ask yourself why you program at all, not because you are necessarily a bad programmer or you shouldn’t do it, but because these are motivations unlikely to come to fruition consistently and will almost inevitably lead to disappointment or regret. •Praise/Recognition: You want to receive this from your family/friends/teachers/potential employers/people you are attracted to. This is inconsistent and wanes fairly quickly. •Money/Material Rewards: You want to use your skills to make a program that others will give this to use. Although possible, this is supremely difficult and largely based on luck. There are very many amazingly well crafted programs which become swept under the rug and ultimately are forgotten simply because the right people didn’t find them. • Full Knowledge of How It All Works: It may not seem like it, but no one knows everything there is to know about a programming language or any other part of programming, with the possible exceptions of extremely basic languages. With those stated, it’s important to take note of some better motivations, such as those in the following hierarchy from the best at the top downward. •Personal Enjoyment: This is the best motivation you can have at this stage. If you do not enjoy it at this point, I would recommend shelving it until/unless you need it. At this point, you need not worry about due dates, team cooperation, or navigating a jungle of other peoples’ code, so it might cause you some problems when you get to the work world if you don’t find coding worthwhile. • Interest/Curiosity: Even if you don’t necessarily find the act of programming fun, you should enjoy learning how to go about solving a problem with a computer or piecing together the principles behind it all. But be careful not to become frustrated that you do not know how to do everything. It takes years to learn how to do most anything you could coceiveably need to do. •Aspirations for Becoming Better: Think of what all you can do compared to what you could do when you started. Now consider that with practice, you could become much better than you are now. Does the prospect of progress feel satisfying or exciting? If so, then it’s one of the best motivations there is. Otherwise, try something else. However, if both of those were wrong and you just had a difficult time with a problem or something to that tune, then the only advice I can give is to get over it. There will be plenty of problems that are too difficult to solve by brute force. If all problems were direct and easy, there would be little demand for new programmers because just a few would be able to accomplish the same amount as many programmers as a team here and now. Hope I helped.

YES! If you like what you do then go ahead pursue your passion. Don’t just learn them because it will get you into a great school/ pay you well rather, you should try to enjoy them. After reading your description it suggests me that you are probably not enjoying programming because you are doubting yourself. If you do not like it then you can try something new that you think you will enjoy. Personally, I have always enjoyed programming and learning new stuff in general but the most fun part is when I try to program something new or try to program something that I know I am not capable but just to challenge myself. I am just a senior in high school but I enjoy coding in general and I try to connect it with other things that I like to do. IMO, you should keep practicing the languages that you already know and challenge yourself with new stuff. Being the best at the languages that you already know will help you a lot if you want to learn a new language. Like I mentioned before, your description sounds like you don’t really enjoy programming. The reason could be you haven’t gone out of your box yet to code something other than the stuff that is assigned to you (like the stuff on codecademy or something). But yeah good luck!!! Disclaimer: I hope I don't offend anybody while writing an answer. So, if you are offended I apologize; it was unintentional. Also, please forgive me if I have any English grammar errors I often do not proofread my answers on Quora. However, I encourage you to suggest me with any edits that you believe I should make because it helps me learn new things also fix something if I get it wrong. Thank you!

As other people said, as long as you are interested in and enjoying programming, or the learning of programming, by all means continue. If it is just something to do, but not what you want to do, then find something else. There are plenty of other things to do with your life. I was introduced to computers when I was ten, tried to take a programming class at 11 with a teacher who didn’t really know how to teach, and then started teaching myself at 12. I’ve been doing it now for more than 40 years and continue to learn new things constantly. One thing to be aware of: learning a language is just the beginning. As you gain experience, you’ll discover that there are many different ways to accomplish any given task. The best solution in one application may not be appropriate for another. Performance may matter in one project, another might need to emphasize clear and clean code, yet another might need a quick solution that works, but is neither clean nor fast. Have fun with it!

Absolutely. The fact that you have been programming from such a young age is going to give you a leg up in this world. Programming and coding are very quickly going to be come ubiquitous, and the more you know, the better you will set yourself up for success. I’m currently learning software engineering at Holberton School, and only wish that I had started at a younger age. I would recommend working in one language for a few months, do some significant projects in your language of choice, then switch to a new language for a few months. The reason I recommend this is because the ability to transition between languages, frameworks, and technologies is super useful in the industry. Depending on the team or project you are working on, will determine the langue you work in. So if you only master one language, you loose your flexibility to work in other languages.

Yes, you should continue learning programming. Not programming languages. They aren’t the same thing. Practice your craft and hone your skills. It takes many, many years to become truly proficient at programming. Some people say at least 10 years (and I would tend to agree). Java and Python are fine languages. There is absolutely no need to look at other languages until you’ve become truly expert in these. See Richard Kenneth Eng's answer to Which programming language has the best job stability?

Absolutely! Keep learning as long as you’re having fun — and it will be. Definitely keep up Java and Javascript (they’re totally different, despite the similarity in their names, which was done deliberately to confuse people). Other languages you will enjoy are Lisp (its most popular dialect is called Scheme), Ruby, and Haskell. Also the scripting language Bash, which is the command line language on Linux and Mac, and recently became available on Windows 10.

Do you enjoy programming? If so, keep at it, and you might discover a career. If yoi dont enjoy programming, you have at least learned a career that you don't want. Programming will involve life long learning. At the moment, I am reviewing am OS that I thought I was done with 30 years ago. I am learning a new language, and have learned 2 others in the last year. Master the languages you use, and be prepared to learn and master new ones when needed.

I've been programming for 20+ years and still learn new things, but I enjoy it. If you enjoy it, then by all means continue. If you don't enjoy it, then stop. I think your satisfaction gained from programming should be your indicator of whether or not to continue.

you know what i feel sad when i think of my past that i didn’t knew programming at an early age … believe me..continue with these stuff and you will feel the wonders ahead … #a new prodigy in process kudos!!:)
Yes. My advice is that to use your programming skills with hardware. Get an Arduino or a Raspberry and program them to make things move.

I’d advice that you apply your knowledge on something concrete and that way learn even more. The languages and markups you are mentioning are certainly bankable. See if there are any projects you could build that would have an external effect.
If you have will to do something, why you should to stop?.
